paragraphs.translated: 尽管从经验上看，使用有机策略对你更有利，但你也可以通过这种方法取得成功。你只需要更加自律。当你采用有机方法时，除非有证据表明确实缺少了什么，否则你甚至不会注意到某个想法。

paragraphs.original: But when you make a conscious effort to think of startup ideas, you have to replace this natural constraint with self-discipline. You'll see a lot more ideas, most of them bad, so you need to be able to filter them.One of the biggest dangers of not using the organic method is the example of the organic method.
paragraphs.translated: 但当你有意识地努力思考创业点子时，你必须用自律来替代这种自然的限制。你会看到更多的点子，其中大多数都是不好的，所以你需要有能力筛选它们。不使用自然方法的一个最大危险就是自然方法的例子。

paragraphs.original: Organic ideas feel like inspirations. There are a lot of stories about successful startups that began when the founders had what seemed a crazy idea but "just knew" it was promising. When you feel that about an idea you've had while trying to come up with startup ideas, you're probably mistaken.When searching for ideas, look in areas where you have some expertise.
paragraphs.translated: 有机的想法感觉像是灵感。有很多关于成功创业公司的故事，这些公司都是从创始人看似疯狂但“直觉”到有前景的想法开始的。当你在尝试想出创业点子时，对某个想法有这种感觉，你可能就错了。在寻找点子时，应该关注你有专业背景的领域。

paragraphs.original: If you're a database expert, don't build a chat app for teenagers (unless you're also a teenager). Maybe it's a good idea, but you can't trust your judgment about that, so ignore it. There have to be other ideas that involve databases, and whose quality you can judge.
paragraphs.translated: 如果你是数据库专家，就不要为青少年构建聊天应用（除非你也是青少年）。这也许是个好主意，但你无法信任自己对这个想法的判断，所以忽略它。一定还有其他涉及数据库的想法，而你可以对它们的质量做出判断。

paragraphs.original: Do you find it hard to come up with good ideas involving databases? That's because your expertise raises your standards. Your ideas about chat apps are just as bad, but you're giving yourself a Dunning-Kruger pass in that domain.The place to start looking for ideas is things you need.
paragraphs.translated: 你觉得很难想出涉及数据库的好点子？那是因为你的专业水平提高了你的标准。你对聊天应用的想法同样糟糕，但在那个领域你却给自己开了一个邓宁-克鲁格效应的通行证。寻找点子的起点应该是你自己的需求。

paragraphs.original: There must be things you need. [14]One good trick is to ask yourself whether in your previous job you ever found yourself saying "Why doesn't someone make x? If someone made x we'd buy it in a second." If you can think of any x people said that about, you probably have an idea.
paragraphs.translated: 总有些东西是你需要的。一个好方法是问问自己，在你之前的工作中，你是否曾经说过“为什么没有人做出x来？如果有人做出x，我们肯定会立刻买。”如果你能想到任何人们曾经这样说过的东西，那你很可能就有了一个点子。

paragraphs.original: You know there's demand, and people don't say that about things that are impossible to build.More generally, try asking yourself whether there's something unusual about you that makes your needs different from most other people's.
paragraphs.translated: 你知道有需求，人们不会对那些不可能实现的事情说有需求。更广泛地说，试着问问自己，是否有某些不同寻常的地方，使你的需求与大多数人的需求不同。

paragraphs.original: You're probably not the only one. It's especially good if you're different in a way people will increasingly be.If you're changing ideas, one unusual thing about you is the idea you'd previously been working on.
paragraphs.translated: 你可能不是唯一的。如果你与众不同之处是人们日益增长的特质，那就更好了。如果你在改变想法，那么你之前研究的那个想法就是你与众不同的一点。

paragraphs.original: Did you discover any needs while working on it? Several well-known startups began this way. Hotmail began as something its founders wrote to talk about their previous startup idea while they were working at their day jobs.
paragraphs.translated: 你在做这件事的过程中发现任何需求了吗？一些知名创业公司就是这样起步的。Hotmail 起初是其创始人在白天工作之余，为了讨论他们之前的创业想法而编写的一个工具。

paragraphs.original: [15]A particularly promising way to be unusual is to be young. Some of the most valuable new ideas take root first among people in their teens and early twenties. And while young founders are at a disadvantage in some respects, they're the only ones who really understand their peers.
paragraphs.translated: [15]一个特别有希望的方式是保持年轻。一些最有价值的新想法首先在十几岁和二十岁出头的人群中生根。虽然年轻的创始人在某些方面处于劣势，但他们是对同龄人真正了解的唯一群体。

paragraphs.original: It would have been very hard for someone who wasn't a college student to start Facebook. So if you're a young founder (under 23 say), are there things you and your friends would like to do that current technology won't let you?The next best thing to an unmet need of your own is an unmet need of someone else.
paragraphs.translated: 如果不是大学生的话，创建Facebook将会非常困难。所以，如果你是一位年轻的创始人（比如23岁以下），你和你的朋友是否有想做的事情是当前技术无法实现的？仅次于自己未满足需求的，就是他人的未满足需求。

paragraphs.original: Try talking to everyone you can about the gaps they find in the world. What's missing? What would they like to do that they can't? What's tedious or annoying, particularly in their work? Let the conversation get general; don't be trying too hard to find startup ideas.
paragraphs.translated: 试着与你能接触到的每个人交谈，了解他们发现的世界中的不足之处。缺少了什么？有什么是他们想做却做不到的？特别是在工作中，哪些事情让他们感到繁琐或厌烦？让谈话内容广泛一些；不要太刻意地去寻找创业点子。

paragraphs.original: You're just looking for something to spark a thought. Maybe you'll notice a problem they didn't consciously realize they had, because you know how to solve it.When you find an unmet need that isn't your own, it may be somewhat blurry at first.
paragraphs.translated: 你只是在寻找能够激发思考的点。也许你会注意到他们尚未意识到的问题，因为你懂得如何解决它。当你发现一个不是你自身的需求时，它可能最初会显得有些模糊。

paragraphs.original: The person who needs something may not know exactly what they need. In that case I often recommend that founders act like consultants — that they do what they'd do if they'd been retained to solve the problems of this one user.
paragraphs.translated: 需要某样东西的人可能并不清楚自己具体需要什么。在这种情况下，我常常建议创始人像顾问一样行事——就像他们被聘请来解决这个用户的问题一样。

paragraphs.original: People's problems are similar enough that nearly all the code you write this way will be reusable, and whatever isn't will be a small price to start out certain that you've reached the bottom of the well.
paragraphs.translated: 人们的问题足够相似，以至于你用这种方式编写的几乎所有代码都可以重用，而那些不能重用的部分，开始时所付出的代价也相对较小，可以确保你已经找到了问题的根源。

paragraphs.original: [16]One way to ensure you do a good job solving other people's problems is to make them your own. When Rajat Suri of E la Carte decided to write software for restaurants, he got a job as a waiter to learn how restaurants worked.
paragraphs.translated: [16]确保你能够很好地解决别人的问题的一个方法是将这些问题变成自己的。当E la Carte的拉贾特·苏里决定为餐馆编写软件时，他找了一份服务员的工作来了解餐馆的运作方式。

paragraphs.original: That may seem like taking things to extremes, but startups are extreme. We love it when founders do such things.In fact, one strategy I recommend to people who need a new idea is not merely to turn off their schlep and unsexy filters, but to seek out ideas that are unsexy or involve schleps.
paragraphs.translated: 这听起来可能有些过头了，但初创企业本身就是极端的。我们非常喜欢创始人这样做。事实上，我向需要新点子的人推荐的一个策略不仅是关闭他们的“苦差”和“不性感”过滤器，而是主动寻找那些不性感或涉及苦差的点子。

paragraphs.original: Don't try to start Twitter. Those ideas are so rare that you can't find them by looking for them. Make something unsexy that people will pay you for.A good trick for bypassing the schlep and to some extent the unsexy filter is to ask what you wish someone else would build, so that you could use it.
paragraphs.translated: 不要试图创办推特。这样的创意非常稀有，你不可能通过刻意寻找而得到。去做一些不那么吸引人但人们愿意为之付费的事情。一个绕过辛苦劳动和某种程度上不那么吸引人过滤器的好方法是，想想你希望有人能为你创建什么，这样你就可以使用它。

paragraphs.original: What would you pay for right now?Since startups often garbage-collect broken companies and industries, it can be a good trick to look for those that are dying, or deserve to, and try to imagine what kind of company would profit from their demise.
paragraphs.translated: 你现在愿意为什么付出？由于初创公司经常清理破产的公司和行业，一个不错的策略是寻找那些正在消亡或应该消亡的公司，然后尝试想象有哪些公司能从它们的衰落中获利。

paragraphs.original: For example, journalism is in free fall at the moment. But there may still be money to be made from something like journalism. What sort of company might cause people in the future to say "this replaced journalism" on some axis?But imagine asking that in the future, not now.
paragraphs.translated: 例如，新闻业目前正处于自由落体状态。但也许仍然可以从类似新闻业的领域赚到钱。什么样的公司可能会让未来的人们说“这在某些方面取代了新闻业”？但想象一下这个问题是在未来而不是现在提出的。

paragraphs.original: When one company or industry replaces another, it usually comes in from the side. So don't look for a replacement for x; look for something that people will later say turned out to be a replacement for x.
paragraphs.translated: 当一个公司或行业被另一个取代时，通常是从侧面进入的。所以不要去找x的替代品；而要去找那些后来人们会说原来是x的替代品的东西。

paragraphs.original: And be imaginative about the axis along which the replacement occurs. Traditional journalism, for example, is a way for readers to get information and to kill time, a way for writers to make money and to get attention, and a vehicle for several different types of advertising.
paragraphs.translated: 并且对于替代发生的轴要有创造力。例如，传统新闻业是读者获取信息和消磨时间的方式，是作家赚钱和获得关注的途径，也是多种类型广告的载体。

paragraphs.original: It could be replaced on any of these axes (it has already started to be on most).When startups consume incumbents, they usually start by serving some small but important market that the big players ignore.
paragraphs.translated: 它可以在这些轴中的任何一个上被替代（在大多数轴上已经开始）。当初创公司吞噬现有企业时，通常是从服务某个小但重要的市场开始的，而大公司往往忽视了这个市场。

paragraphs.original: It's particularly good if there's an admixture of disdain in the big players' attitude, because that often misleads them. For example, after Steve Wozniak built the computer that became the Apple I, he felt obliged to give his then-employer Hewlett-Packard the option to produce it.
paragraphs.translated: 如果大玩家的态度中带有轻蔑，那就更好了，因为这往往会误导他们。例如，史蒂夫·沃兹尼亚克制造了后来成为苹果I的计算机后，感到有义务给他的当时雇主惠普公司提供生产它的机会。

paragraphs.original: Fortunately for him, they turned it down, and one of the reasons they did was that it used a TV for a monitor, which seemed intolerably déclassé to a high-end hardware company like HP was at the time.
paragraphs.translated: 幸运的是，他们拒绝了，其中一个原因是它使用了电视作为显示器，这在当时像惠普这样的高端硬件公司看来，显得无法忍受的低档。

paragraphs.original: [17]Are there groups of scruffy but sophisticated users like the early microcomputer "hobbyists" that are currently being ignored by the big players? A startup with its sights set on bigger things can often capture a small market easily by expending an effort that wouldn't be justified by that market alone.Similarly, since the most successful startups generally ride some wave bigger than themselves, it could be a good trick to look for waves and ask how one could benefit from them.
paragraphs.translated: [17] 是否存在一些被大公司忽视的、外表邋遢但极为精明的用户群体，就像早期的微型计算机“爱好者”那样？一家志向远大的创业公司往往可以通过付出对那个小市场本身来说不值得的努力而轻松占领该市场。同样，由于最成功的创业公司通常会乘上比自身更大的浪潮，寻找这些浪潮并思考如何从中受益可能是一个不错的策略。

paragraphs.original: The prices of gene sequencing and 3D printing are both experiencing Moore's Law-like declines. What new things will we be able to do in the new world we'll have in a few years? What are we unconsciously ruling out as impossible that will soon be possible?
paragraphs.translated: 基因测序和3D打印的价格都正在经历类似摩尔定律的下降。几年后，在我们即将拥有的新世界里，我们将能够做哪些新的事情？我们无意识地认为不可能的事情中，有哪些很快就会成为可能？

paragraphs.original: OrganicBut talking about looking explicitly for waves makes it clear that such recipes are plan B for getting startup ideas. Looking for waves is essentially a way to simulate the organic method. If you're at the leading edge of some rapidly changing field, you don't have to look for waves; you are the wave.Finding startup ideas is a subtle business, and that's why most people who try fail so miserably.
paragraphs.translated: 但是，明确地寻找机会表明，这样的方法实际上是获取创业点子的备选方案。寻找机会本质上是模拟自然方法的一种方式。如果你处于某个快速变化领域的前沿，你就无需寻找机会；你本身就是那个机会。发现创业点子是一项微妙的工作，这也是为什么大多数尝试的人都会惨败。

paragraphs.original: It doesn't work well simply to try to think of startup ideas. If you do that, you get bad ones that sound dangerously plausible. The best approach is more indirect: if you have the right sort of background, good startup ideas will seem obvious to you.
paragraphs.translated: 仅仅试图想出创业点子是行不通的。如果这样做，你会得到一些听起来危险地可信的糟糕点子。最好的方法更为间接：如果你有合适的背景，好的创业点子对你来说会显得显而易见。

paragraphs.original: But even then, not immediately. It takes time to come across situations where you notice something missing. And often these gaps won't seem to be ideas for companies, just things that would be interesting to build.
paragraphs.translated: 但即使如此，也不会立即发生。需要时间才能遇到让你注意到某些缺失的情况。而往往这些缺失看起来并不像是可以成立公司的点子，而只是些有趣的东西，值得去构建。

paragraphs.original: Which is why it's good to have the time and the inclination to build things just because they're interesting.Live in the future and build what seems interesting. Strange as it sounds, that's the real recipe.
paragraphs.translated: 这就是为什么有时间和兴趣去建造一些有趣的东西是件好事。生活在未来，建造那些看似有趣的事物。听起来可能有些奇怪，但这才是真正的方法。

paragraphs.original: Notes[1] This form of bad idea has been around as long as the web. It was common in the 1990s, except then people who had it used to say they were going to create a portal for x instead of a social network for x.
paragraphs.translated: 注[1] 这种糟糕的想法自互联网诞生之日起就一直存在。在20世纪90年代，这种想法非常普遍，只不过当时的人们会说他们打算为某个领域创建一个门户网站，而不是为某个领域创建一个社交网络。

paragraphs.original: Structurally the idea is stone soup: you post a sign saying "this is the place for people interested in x," and all those people show up and you make money from them. What lures founders into this sort of idea are statistics about the millions of people who might be interested in each type of x.
paragraphs.translated: 从结构上来说，这个想法就像是石头汤：你竖起一个牌子，写着“这是对x感兴趣的人的地方”，所有这些人都会来，然后你从他们身上赚到钱。吸引创始人进入这种想法的是关于可能对每种x感兴趣的数百万人的统计数据。

paragraphs.original: What they forget is that any given person might have 20 affinities by this standard, and no one is going to visit 20 different communities regularly.[2] I'm not saying, incidentally, that I know for sure a social network for pet owners is a bad idea.
paragraphs.translated: 他们忘记的是，按照这个标准，任何一个人可能有20种兴趣归属，而没有人会经常访问20个不同的社区。顺便说一句，我并不是肯定地说我知道为宠物主人建立社交网络是个坏主意。

paragraphs.original: I know it's a bad idea the way I know randomly generated DNA would not produce a viable organism. The set of plausible sounding startup ideas is many times larger than the set of good ones, and many of the good ones don't even sound that plausible.
paragraphs.translated: 我知道这是一个糟糕的主意，就像我知道随机生成的DNA不会产生可行的生物一样。听起来合理的创业想法的数量远远大于真正好的想法的数量，而且许多好的想法甚至听起来并不那么可信。

paragraphs.original: So if all you know about a startup idea is that it sounds plausible, you have to assume it's bad.[3] More precisely, the users' need has to give them sufficient activation energy to start using whatever you make, which can vary a lot.
paragraphs.translated: 所以，如果你对一个创业点子的了解仅限于它听起来合理，你就必须假设它是不好的。[3] 更准确地说，用户的需求必须能够给予他们足够的激活能，以开始使用你所创造的东西，而这可以有很大的差异。

paragraphs.original: For example, the activation energy for enterprise software sold through traditional channels is very high, so you'd have to be a lot better to get users to switch. Whereas the activation energy required to switch to a new search engine is low.
paragraphs.translated: 例如，通过传统渠道销售的企业软件的激活能非常高，因此要想让用户切换，你必须好得多。而切换到新的搜索引擎所需的激活能则很低。

paragraphs.original: Which in turn is why search engines are so much better than enterprise software.[4] This gets harder as you get older. While the space of ideas doesn't have dangerous local maxima, the space of careers does.
paragraphs.translated: 这也就是为什么搜索引擎比企业软件要好得多。[4] 随着年龄的增长，这一点变得越来越难。虽然想法的空间没有危险的局部最大值，但职业空间却有。

paragraphs.original: There are fairly high walls between most of the paths people take through life, and the older you get, the higher the walls become.[5] It was also obvious to us that the web was going to be a big deal.
paragraphs.translated: 人们在生命中所走的大多数路径之间都有相当高的墙，而且你年纪越大，这些墙就越高。[5] 我们也明显意识到，互联网将是一件大事。

paragraphs.original: Few non-programmers grasped that in 1995, but the programmers had seen what GUIs had done for desktop computers.[6] Maybe it would work to have this second self keep a journal, and each night to make a brief entry listing the gaps and anomalies you'd noticed that day.
paragraphs.translated: 1995年，很少有非程序员理解这一点，但程序员们已经看到了图形用户界面（GUI）对桌面计算机的影响。也许可以让这个第二自我保持写日记的习惯，每天晚上简要记录下你当天注意到的空白和异常。

paragraphs.original: Not startup ideas, just the raw gaps and anomalies.[7] Sam Altman points out that taking time to come up with an idea is not merely a better strategy in an absolute sense, but also like an undervalued stock in that so few founders do it.There's comparatively little competition for the best ideas, because few founders are willing to put in the time required to notice them.
paragraphs.translated: 不是创业点子，只是原始的缺口和异常现象。[7] 萨姆·阿尔特曼指出，花时间想出一个点子不仅在绝对意义上是一个更好的策略，而且就像被低估的股票一样，因为很少有创始人这么做。对于最好的点子，竞争相对较少，因为很少有创始人愿意花时间去发现它们。

paragraphs.original: Whereas there is a great deal of competition for mediocre ideas, because when people make up startup ideas, they tend to make up the same ones.[8] For the computer hardware and software companies, summer jobs are the first phase of the recruiting funnel.
paragraphs.translated: 平庸的创意却有大量的竞争，因为当人们构思创业点子时，往往会想到相同的点子。对于计算机硬件和软件公司来说，暑期工作是招聘漏斗的第一阶段。

paragraphs.original: But if you're good you can skip the first phase. If you're good you'll have no trouble getting hired by these companies when you graduate, regardless of how you spent your summers.[9] The empirical evidence suggests that if colleges want to help their students start startups, the best thing they can do is leave them alone in the right way.[10] I'm speaking here of IT startups; in biotech things are different.[11] This is an instance of a more general rule: focus on users, not competitors.
paragraphs.translated: 但如果你足够优秀，就可以跳过第一阶段。如果你足够优秀，当你毕业时，无论你如何度过暑假，这些公司都会毫不犹豫地聘用你。[9] 实证研究表明，如果大学希望帮助学生创办初创企业，最好的办法就是以正确的方式放手不管。[10] 这里我说的是IT初创企业；在生物技术领域情况则不同。[11] 这是一个更普遍规则的实例：关注用户，而不是竞争对手。

paragraphs.original: The most important information about competitors is what you learn via users anyway.[12] In practice most successful startups have elements of both. And you can describe each strategy in terms of the other by adjusting the boundaries of what you call the market.
paragraphs.translated: 关于竞争对手最重要的信息是通过用户了解到的。实际上，大多数成功的初创公司都兼具这两种策略的元素。你可以通过调整所定义的市场的边界，用一种策略来描述另一种策略。

paragraphs.original: But it's useful to consider these two ideas separately.[13] I almost hesitate to raise that point though. Startups are businesses; the point of a business is to make money; and with that additional constraint, you can't expect you'll be able to spend all your time working on what interests you most.[14] The need has to be a strong one.
paragraphs.translated: 但将这两个想法分开考虑是有用的。[13] 虽然我几乎犹豫是否要提出这一点。初创公司是企业；企业的目的是赚钱；有了这一额外的限制，你不能期望能将所有时间都花在你最感兴趣的事情上。[14] 这种需求必须是强烈的。

paragraphs.original: You can retroactively describe any made-up idea as something you need. But do you really need that recipe site or local event aggregator as much as Drew Houston needed Dropbox, or Brian Chesky and Joe Gebbia needed Airbnb?Quite often at YC I find myself asking founders "Would you use this thing yourself, if you hadn't written it?" and you'd be surprised how often the answer is no.[15] Paul Buchheit points out that trying to sell something bad can be a source of better ideas:"The best technique I've found for dealing with YC companies that have bad ideas is to tell them to go sell the product ASAP (before wasting time building it).
paragraphs.translated: 你可以事后将任何虚构的想法描述为某种你需要的东西。但你真的像德鲁·休斯顿需要Dropbox，或者布莱恩·切斯基和乔·杰比亚需要Airbnb那样，需要那个食谱网站或本地活动聚合器吗？在YC，我经常发现自己会问创始人：“如果你没有编写它，你会使用这个东西吗？”你可能会惊讶地发现，答案往往是不。[15] 保罗·布赫海特指出，试图推销糟糕的东西可能是更好想法的来源：“我发现在处理YC公司中那些有糟糕想法的公司时，最好的方法是告诉他们尽快去销售产品（在浪费时间构建它之前）。”

paragraphs.original: Not only do they learn that nobody wants what they are building, they very often come back with a real idea that they discovered in the process of trying to sell the bad idea."[16] Here's a recipe that might produce the next Facebook, if you're college students.
paragraphs.translated: 他们不仅会发现没有人需要他们正在开发的东西，而且还经常会带着一个在尝试推销这个糟糕主意的过程中发现的真实想法回来。[16] 如果你是大学生，这里有一个可能孕育出下一个Facebook的配方。

paragraphs.original: If you have a connection to one of the more powerful sororities at your school, approach the queen bees thereof and offer to be their personal IT consultants, building anything they could imagine needing in their social lives that didn't already exist.
paragraphs.translated: 如果你和你学校的某个更有影响力的姐妹会有联系，可以接近她们的领袖，提出担任她们的个人IT顾问，构建她们在社交生活中可能需要但尚未存在的任何东西。

paragraphs.original: Anything that got built this way would be very promising, because such users are not just the most demanding but also the perfect point to spread from.I have no idea whether this would work.[17] And the reason it used a TV for a monitor is that Steve Wozniak started out by solving his own problems.
paragraphs.translated: 任何以这种方式构建的事物都极具潜力，因为这类用户不仅是要求最高的，也是最理想的传播起点。我不知道这是否会奏效。[17] 而它使用电视作为显示器的原因是，史蒂夫·沃兹尼亚克最初是为了解决自己的问题。
